definitions.definition: hard; not in the form of a liquid or gas

examples.text: The planet Jupiter may have no solid surface at all.
The boat bumped against a solid object.
She had refused all solid food.
the collection and disposal of **solid waste**
It was so cold that the stream had frozen solid.
The boiler uses **solid fuel** *(= for example, coal)*.
The ice felt solid enough.
Under her bare toes the floor felt real and solid.

definitions.definition: having no holes or spaces inside; not hollow

examples.text: They were drilling through solid rock.
He flung open the solid wood door.
The stores are packed solid *(= very full and crowded)* at this time of year.
The national boundary is shown on the map as a **solid line**.

definitions.definition: made completely of the material mentioned (that is, the material is not only on the surface)

examples.text: a solid gold bracelet
Each piece is individually made in solid silver.
These chains seem fairly solid.
The door was solid as rock.

definitions.definition: that you can rely on; having a strong basis

examples.text: As yet, they have no solid evidence.
His advice was always solid and practical.
This provided a **solid foundation** for their marriage.
We've established a really **solid base** for our products.
The Irish team were **solid as a rock** in defence.

definitions.definition: definitely good and steady but perhaps not excellent or special

examples.text: 2017 was a year of solid achievement.
Both leading actors put in a **solid performance**.
He's a **good solid** player.
The songwriting quality is consistently solid.
Trade remained solid throughout the year.
The essay represents a solid week's work.
It rained for two hours solid this afternoon.

definitions.definition: of the colour mentioned and no other colour

examples.text: One cat is black and white, the other solid black.

definitions.definition: a shape that is solid has length, width and height and is not flat

examples.text: A cube is a solid figure.

definitions.definition: in complete agreement; agreed on by everyone

examples.text: The department was solid against the changes.
The strike was solid, supported by all the members.

definitions.definition: to be in a strong position in an argument, etc. because you know the facts

examples.text: Everyone agreed with me, so I knew I was on firm ground.
He is probably on solid ground when he says we need more training.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin solidus; related to salvus ‘safe’ and sollus ‘entire’.
